results.title: We interrupt this program
results.creator_credit: Clavius Base, Imagine Entertainment (US), Brian Grazer, Ron Howard, Michael Bostick and David Frankel
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “From the earth to the moon”.
On April 13, 1970, Apollo 13, the 23rd manned flight into space, developed problems that threatened the lives of the astronauts on board. The complacency which had accompanied the launch and the disinterest of the general public throughout the mission until problems occurred were quickly dispelled, as every move was monitored by journalists who fed the story to a hungry audience fast becoming hooked on sensationalism. A divide was growing wider between the traditions of the intellectual press and the fast-feed emotional content of the new tabloid journalism.

results.title: We have to start somewhere
results.creator_credit: Banks Noel Paton, Peter Richman and Eric Fullilove
results.brief_description: This film is about development. Focussing on the discussion group that appears in the film has a connection with the title of the film. The group covers, among other things, migrants, Aborigines and the relationships between rich and poor nations and the consequences of preaching Christianity without due reverence for other cultures. The film stresses the need for commitment to action

results.title: We have cleared the tower
results.creator_credit: Clavius Base, Imagine Entertainment (US), Brian Grazer, Ron Howard and Michael Bostick
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “From the earth to the moon”.
19 months and six unmanned flights after the Apollo 1 tragedy, Wally Schirra, Don Eisele and Walt Cunningham are set to become the first trio of American astronauts in space on Apollo 7 - their preparations followed every step of the way by a keen, young documentary crew. Noone can afford to make a mistake that might endanger the life of the mission or the lives of the men.

results.title: We grow here
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Interviews with Sicilian migrants who ended up making the lush lands of Northern Queensland their home. The men and women describe the hardship of their lives in Sicily, talk about their initial impressions on arrival in Australia and explore their sometimes ambivalent attachments to their two “homelands”.

results.title: We grow apricots
results.brief_description: Describes life in an apricot orchard in the irrigation area of the Goulbourn Valley. Shows the full cycle of fruit growing and canning over the year.

results.title: We grew a frog
results.creator_credit: Boulton-Hawker Films, Peter Boulton and Nigel Rea
results.brief_description:
Records an activity in which children collect and rear frog spawn in a tank at their school. Covers each stage in the development of the frog, showing details not easily seen in a classroom aquarium.
Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: We don't want to live on our knees
results.creator_credit: Granada Television International and Julia Spark
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “History in action”.
On 2nd August 1968, Soviet planes and tanks invaded Czechoslovakia. The invasion came as a surprise because only two weeks before a meeting at Bratislava between Dubcek, Secretary of the Czech Communist Party and the entire Russian Politbureau appeared to have gone well. Why then was Czechoslovakia invaded, and why did the Russians fear the new freedoms which had taken place?

results.title: We don't make him special
results.creator_credit: I E A, Marjorie Fisher, Joan Reidy and Peter Brighton
results.brief_description: The story of the integration into life’s normal activities of a Down’s syndrome child as related by his mother. The acceptance of the child into the school community is effectively portrayed enabling the program to be utilised by a school contemplating the integration of disabled students. A positive program that supports the belief that the whole community benefits from the integration of disabled people into society.
